title: Can this Off Road 'Wheelchair' handle SNOW?!
description: Customize your own 'Not-a-Wheelchair' right here:  The trail was about 2 or 3 miles long before the snow got too soft and we had to turn back. We wanted to create something affordable, and capable and I think we've done it. Huge thanks to Utah Trikes for their help designing and manufacturing The Rig. We hope it brings as many miles of happiness, adventure, and exploration to you as it has done for us. Designing an affordable bike that happens to be accommodating has taken us more than a year and a half. Of course we plan on building and improving The Rig over the next few years. We welcome all suggestions for improvement in the comments! Let us know what you think!   Watch our launch video for more information:  Come follow us on Instagram for updates:   Like any activity, riding the Not-a-Wheelchair involves the risk of injury and damage. By choosing to ride a Not-a-Wheelchair, you assume full responsibility for the risks. Know the rules of safe and responsible riding and practice them. It is up to you to ensure you know how to use and maintain your vehicle. Be sure to always ride with a helmet and/or protective gear. Be aware of all applicable laws which may govern the use of this product in public areas as this product is not to be used in such instances which may violate local laws and/or in public areas which may cause injuries or accidents to bystanders.   See full ADA requirements for Other Power driven Mobility Devices here:    *Follow me for updates!* Instagram:  Facebook:  Twitter:   LARGE tool kit:  Travel Tool Kit:  Green Pry tool:  Metal phone opening tool:   The camera I used to film this video:  The Lens I used for this video:  Wide angle lens:  And this Metabones adapter:  This is the drone I use:   TO SEND ME STUFF: See my P.0. Box on my 'About page':   JerryRigEverything assumes no liability for property damage or injury incurred as a result of any of the information contained in this video.  JerryRigEverything recommends safe practices when working with power tools, automotive lifts, lifting tools, jack stands, electrical equipment, blunt instruments, chemicals, lubricants, expensive electronics, or any other tools or equipment seen or implied in this video.  Due to factors beyond the control of JerryRigEverything, no information contained in this video shall create any express or implied warranty or guarantee of any particular result.  Any injury, damage or loss that may result from improper use of these tools, equipment, or the information contained in this video is the sole responsibility of the user and not JerryRigEverything. Only attempt your own repairs if you can accept personal responsibility for the results, whether they are good or bad.
transcript: [quite tires rolling through snow with a silent electric motor] [Music] -[Cambry] Loads of fun. You feel like you're playing Mario Kart in real life. We are up the canyon today about to try out two of the off-road chairs in the snow. They've never been in snow before, so we are going to test them out. -[Zack] Getting both bikes into the back of the truck was a unique experience. I'll let you watch that. So we designed this off-road wheelchair to fit in the bed of a short bed pick up. This bed is 5 feet long. And so it fits very snugly. But today we're going to try to fit two of them in the back of my truck which should be interesting. Normally you wouldn't have to do this and it would be much easier if we had a trailer. But I think if we stack them just right it should work out. Now is that the correct way to do it? Probably not...but it works. I recommend finding more than one person. And today should be interesting. I don't know how the bikes are going to react in snow. It does have the off-road knobby tires on them, but snow is a totally different ball game than pavement, or you know, like a dirt trail. -Let's get started. [Intro] -[Zack] It just latches in like that. Then the wheelchair just sits on the back like that. You can strap it in. It's an all-in-one package. So at the start of the trail, most of it's pretty packed snow so I'm not super worried about it. Two things we have working to our advantage is A) the knobby tires, and B) the solid rear axle where, you know, the rear tires won't spin independently of each other, so they won't lose traction on the snow. But after this initial steep slope, everything else is pretty flat so we should be okay. Alright! -[Cambry] Got it! Ready to bring yours? -[Zack] Yeah. Now it's my turn. I weigh 205 pounds, quite a bit more than Cambry, so we'll see if the chair can handle me going up the hill. Come on baby! It's not too bad. I'm maxed out at level 9 though. Still made it. -[Cambry] Yeah! -[Zack] Let's go! -[Cambry] It's like a nice little stroll in the winter wonderland. Oh, we racing?! -[Zack] Yeah! -[Cambry] I'm a little lighter than you. -[Zack] I'm at level 9. -[Cambry] I'm at 7! Only 7! Woo! A little fishtailing. -[Zack] I'm currently maxed out at 10 miles an hour. -[Cambry] Just going up the mountain enjoying beautiful views. -[Zack] This is working much better than I anticipated. The locked rear axle was a good choice, and all of the bikes have that solid rear axle. Normally you see rear lockers on like off-roading jeeps or trucks. My own truck has it as well. And now the off-road wheelchair has one. -We're definitely at max speed now! -[Zack] So what do you think so far Cambry? -I think it's way fun. I think it's better than a snowmobile. I've once tried that and I was always afraid that my legs were going to get burned. This is so much safer for my body and I love it. -And what about the noise level? -It's way less than the snowmobile's for sure, so you can enjoy nature a little bit better than you would on a lousy gas-powered machine. -Lousy. That's gonna have some angry comments. -It's getting deeper. I'm slowing down. Whoa! Made it. It's a bit of a bumpy ride. -Yeah, I think my heavier weight has more of an advantage in the snow because I have more traction on the back tires. -Yeah, I think he's weighing it down more than I am. -But if you had the chair on the back, that would help out your traction. But we're still going 8 miles an hour. -Whoa! -[Zack] Your back wheels are losing traction a little bit. -[Cambry] I can feel them kind of like fishtail. -[Zack] Yeah, when the snow gets deeper. -[Cambry] It's fun though. I mean, I'm not totally out of control...just a little crazy. -[Zack] You can do it Cambry. You can do it! -[Cambry] I think I can, I think I can. -[Zack] Well... -[Cambry] Well...it's been fun. It's been real fun! -[Zack] The snow's getting deeper. -[Cambry] Oh no! -[Zack] I'm losing it again. Yeah. This is definitely the end for me. And I'm dead. Come on! What seems to be the problem? -[Cambry] I just needed a little slow down time. The snow got a little deep, that's all. Safety first. Alright, race you back! How does that song go? I can't feel my face when I'm with you? -Yeah, something like that. [Music] -[Cambry] My face is frozen! [Music] -[Zack] Ah man, we made it to the bottom! Alright Cambry. So we went off-road. What do you think? -In the snow...not just off-road! -That's true. -I think it was a lot of fun. I haven't been out in the snow and had so much fun in a long time. Downhill is where it's at. Uphill is a little slow and you feel a little bit like The Engine That Could. Isn't that 'I think I can, I think I can'? -Right, right. And slow as in like 8 miles an hour uphill. -[Cambry] Yeah. -[Zack] In packed snow. In loose snow I don't think we'd have a chance. -[Cambry] I don't think we would make it. -[Zack] Downhill is like sledding except for you have control over where you're going and you still have brakes. The brakes work really well. -[Cambry] The brakes, yeah, are really...yeah I've never been scared on this trail thinking I was going to slide off the side of the mountain. -[Zack] Yeah, you stop almost instantly. -[Cambry] Still have caution. -[Zack] Of course. Wear a helmet. -[Cambry] Loads of fun. You feel like you're playing Mario Kart but it's real life. -[Zack] All we need are some banana peels and some blue shells. [Laughing] For when you're in the lead! -[Cambry] It wasn't designed for the snow but we've had a lot of fun with it today. I think it held up pretty well on packed snow. -[Zack] And the wheelchair on the back rack stayed on. I have it tied down with two little Velcro straps. And then the rear wheels just sit inside of those metal channels. -[Cambry] We haven't needed to use the wheelchair on this trip though cuz it was kind of a shorter trip. -[Zack] It was mostly just to prove a point and see how much weight the off-road chair can handle. So I weigh about 200 pounds and the chair weighs about 30 I think. And so the off-road chair is carrying 230 pounds right now. Plus my camera gear and stuff....I would put it around 250 pounds. -[Cambry] We mentioned earlier that it's not loud which is really nice. I think when you slow it down, you can really appreciate the nature that's going on around you. -[Zack] And we don't bother anyone else. Like no one has ever said anything in the year that we've been testing this about being annoyed or about it being loud. It's just like a bicycle. -For me this is better than snowshoeing. [Laughter] -[Zack] Yep. So if you haven't seen the launch video, go watch that. These things are for sale right now whether you need a wheelchair or not, I think it's fun either way...except for the part where we wrecked the drone, I think it went pretty well. Hit that subscribe button if you haven't already. We'll be posting more videos about this and other projects. Come hang out with us on Instagram and Twitter. -And thanks a ton for watching, we'll see you around. -Here's one of those noisy gas-powered...whoa! That was like a motorized sled. -Yeah. Pretty cool.
